Situation1: They guide a patient on proper usage and potential side effects of a new prescription medication.
Expectation2: Arrive at the polling station during designated voting hours
Situation2: Polls stay open all day and the voter has a light schedule.
Story:
I glanced at the clock above the pharmacy counter, noting the hours ticking by. The polling station was open all day, and with my light schedule, I’d planned to vote after lunch. But just as I was about to take my break, Mrs. Patel arrived, clutching a new prescription. She looked anxious, her hands trembling as she handed me the bottle. “I’ve never taken this before,” she whispered. “Will it make me dizzy? What if I forget a dose?” 

I knew my responsibility as a pharmacist was to guide her, to ensure she understood every detail about her medication. She deserved my full attention, my patience, and my expertise. Yet, in the back of my mind, I felt the weight of my civic duty. I’d promised myself I wouldn’t miss voting this year, not with so much at stake. The hours seemed to shrink as I listened to Mrs. Patel’s questions, my mind torn between the needs of my patient and the call to participate in democracy. My heart pounded as I tried to focus, feeling the pressure of two worlds pulling me in opposite directions.
